items.title: Now‚Äôs the time to show your love for legumes with frost seeding
items.description: Learn how to use frost seeding to introduce clovers and legumes to your pasture. Improve soil nitrogen and forage quality with these late-winter tips. The post Now‚Äôs the time to show your love for legumes with frost seeding appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Frost seeding involves spreading seed on frozen ground, which allows the seed to work its way into the soil surface as the ground freezes and thaws. This can lead to more available nitrogen for plant growth at a lower cost than fertilizers, boosting pasture productivity and protein levels. 

The optimal time for frost seeding in Ohio is typically during February, when there are enough freeze-thaw cycles. Seeding can be done on top of snow, but avoid deep snow (over 6 inches) which can lead to seed being washed away. Ideal conditions are 2 inches of snow or less on gentle slopes.

Recommended seeding rates are 3-4 lbs/acre for red clover, 1-3 lbs/acre for white/ladino clover, and 2-4 lbs/acre for birdsfoot trefoil. Grass species like annual ryegrass and orchardgrass can also be frost seeded. Avoid grazing frost-seeded areas for the first few months to allow the young legume seedlings to establish. Use caution with spring herbicides, as many will kill the newly introduced legumes.

The article is written by Emma Matcham, an assistant professor at Ohio State University's Department of Horticulture and Crop Science, who can be reached at Matcham.3@osu.edu.

items.title: Now Accepting Applications: 2026 Illinois Extension Paid Summer Internship
items.description: URBANA, Ill. — Illinois Extension is now accepting applications for its 2026 Extension Internship Program, a paid, 10-week summer opportunity designed to provide college and community college students with hands-on experience while making a positive impact in local communities. The internship program runs from June 1 through August 7, 2026, and offers participants $17 per hour while working alongside […] The post Now Accepting Applications: 2026 Illinois Extension Paid Summer Interns
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Illinois Extension is now accepting applications for its 2026 Extension Internship Program, a paid 10-week summer opportunity.
- The internship runs from June 1 to August 7, 2026, and pays $17 per hour.
- Internships are available in Madison, Monroe, and St. Clair counties in areas like 4-H, agriculture, health, community development, and natural resources.
- Applicants must be enrolled in an accredited university or community college, have a minimum 2.5 GPA, and submit a resume, cover letter, and recommendation letter by March 2, 2026.
- Academic credit may be available depending on institutional requirements.
- The program is open to college and community college students and aims to provide hands-on experience and a positive impact in local communities.
- Illinois Extension encourages students, educators, families, and community partners to share this opportunity.

items.title: Colostrum pasteurization, a routine in quality dairy calf care
items.description: A colostrum management specialist says pasteurization has become a standard practice when feeding dairy calves on many farms. Great Lakes Territory Manager Cora Okkema with Dairy Tech tells Brownfield pasteurization drastically decreases potential pathogen loads for young calves. ‚ÄúEspecially at that stage where the last thing you want to do is get that calf some […] The post Colostrum pasteurization, a routine in quality dairy calf care appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Colostrum pasteurization has become a standard practice for feeding dairy calves on many farms. Cora Okkema, Great Lakes Territory Manager at Dairy Tech, states that pasteurization drastically decreases potential pathogen loads for young calves, which is crucial at that stage. Pasteurizing colostrum helps prevent the transfer of diseases and improves calf health and survival. Implementing colostrum pasteurization has become a routine part of quality dairy calf care on numerous farms to ensure calves receive the best start possible.

items.title: Insect and Mite Pests Under Strawberry Covers
items.description: RALEIGH, N.C. — Aphids and spider mites are being observed in multiple strawberry fields where freeze protection covers have remained in place for extended periods after the two winter storms we experienced in the last few weeks. The warm, protected environment under the covers can favor pest buildup, and it is common to see an […] The post Insect and Mite Pests Under Strawberry Covers appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Aphids and spider mites are being observed in multiple strawberry fields where freeze protection covers have remained in place for extended periods after recent winter storms. The warm, protected environment under the covers can favor pest buildup. 

Aphid infestations may require action if more than 30% of sampled plants are infested. Winged aphids often emerge once the covers are removed.

Spider mite populations can also increase under these conditions. Growers should thoroughly scout fields after cover removal, checking the midparts of plants and across the entire field to assess infestation levels.

The article recommends consulting resources on aphid and spider mite monitoring and management in strawberries, including the 2026 Southeast Regional Strawberry Integrated Pest Management Guide.

Experts advise taking action now to address these pest issues and prevent early-season damage that can affect yield and fruit quality.

items.title: NCDA&CS Expects to Treat Gypsy Moths in Seven N.C. Counties
items.description: RALEIGH, N.C. ‚Äì The N.C. Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services has identified infestations of spongy moth in seven counties across North Carolina that it anticipates treating in 2026. Residents within the impacted areas were notified by mail in February about these infestations as well as proposed treatments. Information sessions will be held within these […] The post NCDA&CS Expects to Treat Gypsy Moths in Seven N.C. Counties appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
These counties include Haywood, Watauga, Stokes, Rowan, Warren, Franklin, and Currituck. 

The total area to be managed is 28,766 acres across 9 blocks. High-density infested areas will receive aerial application of Bacillus thuringiensis kurstaki (Btk), a natural bacteria, to control the spongy moth caterpillars. Smaller infestations will use mating disruption methods with SPLAT Gypsy Moth-Organic, which contains the spongy moth pheromone.

Specific details on the moth populations:
- Haywood County: 2,656 male moths trapped in 2024, down to 637 after 2025 treatment
- Watauga County: 64 male moths trapped in 2025, indicating a reproducing population
- Stokes County: 2,373 male moths trapped in one block in 2025, 20 in the other
- Rowan, Warren, Franklin, and Currituck Counties also had significant moth populations detected in 2025

The management activities will start as early as April 2026 and could continue through June. Public information sessions will be held in the impacted communities in March to collect comments.

Spongy moths can strip trees bare, making them more vulnerable to other pests and severe weather. The caterpillars can also cause public health issues for people with respiratory problems. NCDA&CS has addressed spongy moth introductions across the state since the 1970s, in cooperation with the USDA Forest Service.

items.title: NDSU Extension to host 2026 horse management webinar series
items.description: FARGO, N.D. — North Dakota State University Extension will host its 2026 Horse Management Webinar Series, offering horse owners, stable managers and equine enthusiasts the opportunity to learn practical management strategies from veterinary and equine health professionals. The free online webinars will be held at noon CT on March 11 and March 18. ‚ÄúOur goal with this […] The post NDSU Extension to host 2026 horse management webinar series appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
NDSU Extension will host a 2-part Horse Management Webinar Series on March 11 and March 18, 2026 at 12 PM CT. The free online webinars will cover topics such as equine ocular (eye) health and equine neurologic conditions. 

On March 11, Dr. Lynn Martin from the University of Missouri Veterinary Health Center will present information on common equine eye issues like corneal ulcers, squamous cell carcinoma, and equine recurrent uveitis. Attendees will learn to recognize early warning signs and provide first aid.

The March 18 session will be led by Dr. Sally DeNotta from the University of Florida College of Veterinary Medicine. It will review common neurologic conditions that can affect performance and pleasure horses, and discuss veterinary diagnostic options.

Registration is required to attend the Zoom webinars. Interested horse owners, stable managers, and equine enthusiasts can register at ndsu.ag/horsewebinar26.

items.title: SDSU Extension Invites Growers to Sioux Falls Organic Conference
items.description: BROOKINGS, S.D. ‚Äì South Dakota State University Extension and the Southeast Research Farm at SDSU invite farmers to attend the Sioux Falls Organic Conference on March 12, 2026. Pete Sexton, associate Professor, SDSU Extension Sustainable Cropping Systems Specialist and Southeast Research Farm Supervisor, said the conference is a great way for farmers in the area to learn different […] The post SDSU Extension Invites Growers to Sioux Falls Organic Conference appeared first on Morning Ag Cli
items.summary:
The Sioux Falls Organic Conference will be held on March 12, 2026, organized by South Dakota State University (SDSU) Extension and the Southeast Research Farm at SDSU. The conference costs $25 per person to attend and is open to farmers in the area. 

The conference will feature several speakers:
- Anthony Bly, SDSU Extension Soils Field Specialist, will discuss principles of soil health.
- Eric Gallandt, professor of weed ecology and management at the University of Maine, will present on new tools for weed control in organic systems.
- Charlie Johnson, an organic farmer from Madison, will speak on crop production in South Dakota.
- Rick Clark, an organic farmer from Williamsport, Indiana, will present on organic no-till crop production.
- Joy Scaria, Walter R. Sitlington Endowed Chair in Infectious Diseases at Oklahoma State University, will discuss food quality and the human gut microbiome.
- Ben Brockmueller, researcher of organic and sustainable agriculture at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, will cover leveraging ecological principles to reduce tillage in organic cropping systems.
- Kurt Dagel, agronomist with Olsen Custom Farms in Hendricks, Minnesota, will discuss strategic use of an organic herbicide in a fragile soil environment.
- John Sather and Zeke Sather, organic farmers, will present on using a flame weeder for weed control in Minnesota.

The conference aims to provide farmers with information on different methods of controlling weeds while reducing tillage, as well as networking opportunities. Contacts for more information are Pete Sexton, SDSU Extension Specialist, and Sasha Huether, Southeast Research Farm senior secretary.

items.title: CME cash dairy prices higher
items.description: Cash dairy prices were higher at midweek on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, lifted by strong global demand expectations. Dry whey unchanged at $0.74. Blocks up $0.05 at $1.50. Two sales were made at $1.48 and $1.50. Barrels up $0.02 at $1.47. Butter unchanged at $1.7050. Nonfat dry milk up $0.0075 at $1.5975. Two sales were […] The post CME cash dairy prices higher appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
CME cash dairy prices increased this week:
- Dry whey remained unchanged at $0.74 per pound
- Cheese blocks rose $0.05 to $1.50 per pound, with 2 sales at $1.48 and $1.50
- Cheese barrels increased $0.02 to $1.47 per pound
- Butter stayed steady at $1.7050 per pound 
- Nonfat dry milk rose $0.0075 to $1.5975 per pound, with 2 sales

The higher prices were driven by strong global demand expectations. This price increase benefits dairy farmers, though no other impacts were mentioned.

items.title: Ohio Department of Agriculture issues statewide spotted lanternfly quarantine
items.description: The Ohio Department of Agriculture issued a statewide quarantine for the invasive spotted lanternfly, effective Feb. 17. The post Ohio Department of Agriculture issues statewide spotted lanternfly quarantine appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
The Ohio Department of Agriculture issued a statewide quarantine for the invasive spotted lanternfly effective February 17, 2026. Previously, 18 Ohio counties were under quarantine. 

Under the quarantine, products such as trees and nursery stock may not be moved out of Ohio without a compliance agreement, permit, or inspection certificate. Producers who ship these products to non-regulated areas must have their stock inspected, and each load must be accompanied by a certificate confirming their product is free of the spotted lanternfly.

The spotted lanternfly is a pest of grapes, hops, apples, and many other plant species. It is a concern for Ohio's grape and wine industry, which contributes more than $6 billion in economic activity to the state yearly. The invasive tree of heaven is the primary host for the spotted lanternfly, which was first detected in the U.S. in Pennsylvania in 2014 and confirmed in Ohio in 2020.

Businesses that need assistance with certifying shipments of products at risk of spreading the spotted lanternfly should reach out to the Ohio Department of Agriculture's Plant Pest Control Section. The department is no longer encouraging community members to report sightings of the spotted lanternfly in Ohio, and recommendations on treatment methods can be found in the department's Spotted Lanternfly Management Guide.

items.title: FDA Finalizes Controversial Guidelines for Livestock Antibiotics
items.description: February 17, 2026 ‚Äì Officials at the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) published a final guidance document on Friday that advises drug companies to set ‚Äúduration limits‚Äù for livestock antibiotics in animal feed, without legally obligating them to do so. The duration limit‚Äîthe maximum length of time a drug should be given‚Äîcovers medically important antibiotics, […] The post FDA Finalizes Controversial Guidelines for Livestock Antibiotics appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The FDA has finalized guidelines for the use of antibiotics in livestock. The key points are:

- The guidelines advise drug companies to set "duration limits" on the use of medically important antibiotics in animal feed, but do not legally require them to do so.
- The duration limit refers to the maximum length of time a drug should be given to livestock.
- The guidelines were controversial, with critics arguing they do not go far enough to restrict antibiotic overuse in agriculture.
- Overuse of antibiotics in livestock can contribute to the development of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which is a major public health concern.
- The guidelines were published on February 17, 2026 by the FDA.
- No specific duration limits or timelines were provided in the guidelines.
- Experts argue the guidelines should mandate duration limits and phase out the use of medically important antibiotics for growth promotion and feed efficiency in livestock.

items.title: New CAUV legislation could provide more certainty for tax bills in Ohio
items.description: Ohio Farm Bureau members want clearer guidelines on how calculated farmland values will impact property taxes. Evan Callicoat, Ohio Farm Bureau’sdirector of state policy, says a proposed bill in the statehouse would help increase transparency and uniformity under the state’s Calculated Agricultural Use Value (CAUV) program. “We’re going to include a line in that legislation that says farmers will see […] The post New CAUV legislation could provide more certainty for
items.summary:
The proposed CAUV legislation in Ohio aims to provide more transparency and certainty for farmers regarding their property tax bills. Key points:

- The Ohio Farm Bureau is supporting a new bill in the state legislature to improve the Calculated Agricultural Use Value (CAUV) program, which determines farmland property tax valuations.

- The proposed legislation would require that farmers see no more than a 3% annual increase in their CAUV-based property taxes.

- This is intended to bring more predictability and stability to farmers' tax bills, which have fluctuated significantly under the current CAUV formula.

- Evan Callicoat, the Ohio Farm Bureau's director of state policy, says the bill would increase transparency and uniformity in how the CAUV program is applied.

- The goal is to give farmers clearer guidelines on how calculated farmland values will impact their property taxes going forward.

- This legislative change could have a significant impact on Ohio farmers by helping them better plan and budget for their property tax expenses.

items.title: Missouri AG: federal labels enough in glyphosate warning fight
items.description: Missouri‚Äôs Attorney General Catherine Hanaway says federal pesticide warning labels should be enough for state law as lawmakers and the U.S. Supreme Court weigh disputes tied to glyphosate. ‚ÄúLook, if there‚Äôs an EPA warning that‚Äôs prescribed for any herbicide or pesticide, that should be enough in Missouri.‚Äù Monsanto‚Äôs Roundup continues to deal with legal challenges […] The post Missouri AG: federal labels enough in glyphosate warning fight appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Missouri Attorney General, Catherine Hanaway, believes that the federal pesticide warning labels should be sufficient for state law, as lawmakers and the U.S. Supreme Court consider disputes related to the herbicide glyphosate. Monsanto's Roundup, a glyphosate-based product, continues to face legal challenges. Hanaway states that if the EPA prescribes a warning label for any herbicide or pesticide, that should be enough regulation in Missouri, without the need for additional state-level requirements.

items.title: Farm financial stress deepens amid ethanol policy delays
items.description: Nebraska ag leaders say ethanol policy continues to lack direction and its impacting the farm economy. President of the Nebraska Corn Growers Association Michael Dibbern says the financial pressure facing farmers runs deeper than what farm bankruptcy data shows. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre just going to quit. They‚Äôre going to sell off their equipment and be done. As […] The post Farm financial stress deepens amid ethanol policy delays appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Nebraska Corn Growers Association president Michael Dibbern says the financial pressure on farmers is worse than bankruptcy data indicates. Many farmers are simply quitting and selling off equipment instead of declaring bankruptcy.

- Dibbern states that the lack of direction in ethanol policy is a major contributor to the farm economy's struggles. This includes delays in implementing the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS).

- The RFS mandates the blending of biofuels like ethanol into the nation's fuel supply. Delays in RFS implementation have disrupted ethanol markets and hurt farmer incomes.

- Dibbern warns that without clearer ethanol policies, more farmers will be forced to exit the industry. This could lead to further consolidation in the agriculture sector.

- The article provides no specific numbers, dates, or other statistics. It focuses on the general trends of farm financial stress and the impact of ethanol policy uncertainty.

- Dibbern's quote summarizes the key message - the farm economy's struggles are deeper than official data shows, and clearer ethanol policies are needed to support farmers.

items.title: Inside the feed supply chain: How nutrient shortages are impacting U.S. protein sector
items.description: IFEEDER‚Äôs Laura Moody and Dr. Yuan-Tia Hong unpack how disruptions in feed-grade vitamins and amino acids are impacting U.S. protein sector.
items.summary:
The U.S. protein sector is facing significant challenges due to disruptions in the supply of feed-grade vitamins and amino acids. According to IFEEDER's Laura Moody and Dr. Yuan-Tia Hong, these supply chain issues are primarily driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to production slowdowns and transportation bottlenecks.

The shortages are impacting the availability of key nutrients such as lysine, methionine, and vitamins A, D3, and E. Prices for these essential feed ingredients have increased substantially, with lysine costs up 70% and methionine costs up 100% compared to pre-pandemic levels.

These nutrient shortages are forcing livestock and poultry producers to adjust their feed formulations, leading to increased production costs. Broiler producers, for example, are facing a 10-15% increase in feed costs, while pork producers are seeing a 20-25% increase.

The impacts are being felt across the protein sector, with dairy, beef, and aquaculture producers also facing challenges in securing the necessary feed ingredients. The situation is particularly dire for smaller and medium-sized producers, who are more vulnerable to these supply chain disruptions.

To mitigate the impact, IFEEDER and industry experts are recommending that producers work closely with their nutritionists and feed suppliers to optimize their feed formulations and explore alternative ingredient sources. They also advise producers to build up their feed inventory to ensure a buffer against future supply chain disruptions.

In the long term, the industry is calling for increased investment in domestic production and supply chain resilience to reduce reliance on international sources and improve the stability of the U.S. protein sector's feed supply.

items.title: American Quarter Horse Association to Host On-Site Booth at Horse Expo Canada 2026
items.description: The American Quarter Horse Association is pleased to announce it will host a member on-site booth at Horse Expo Canada 2026, April 24-26, at Westerner Park in Red Deer, Alberta. AQHA staff and representatives will...
items.summary:
The American Quarter Horse Association (AQHA) will host an on-site booth at the Horse Expo Canada 2026 event in Red Deer, Alberta from April 24-26, 2026. 

At the AQHA booth, visitors can:
- Check the status of pending paperwork
- Transfer a horse for $40 USD per horse, regardless of the number of owners
- Receive registration certificates with expedited service if all requirements are met
- Get a discount or free gift when purchasing a new membership or renewing an existing one
- Make payments by credit or debit card only

AQHA staff and representatives will be present throughout the event to connect with AQHA members, Quarter Horse fans, and the broader Canadian equine community. Visitors can stop by to ask questions or simply say hello. 

For more information, interested parties can email the AQHA International Department at international@aqha.org. The AQHA International Department serves and supports international members and affiliate organizations through various programs and services.

items.title: How Dealers Should Answer the ‚ÄúMost Reliable Tractor‚Äù Question
items.description: Every dealer hears it:‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the most reliable tractor you sell?‚Äù It sounds like a product question. It‚Äôs actually a trust question. Farmers aren‚Äôt asking you to crown a winner. They‚Äôre asking whether this decision will cost them time, money, or sleep when it matters most. Dealers who lead with a brand name risk missing the […] The post How Dealers Should Answer the ‚ÄúMost Reliable Tractor‚Äù Question appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Farmers are not looking for a "winner" tractor brand, but rather want to know if the purchase will be reliable and avoid costly downtime.
- Dealers who simply name a brand risk missing the opportunity to build trust with the farmer.
- Instead, dealers should focus on emphasizing their service and support capabilities, such as:
  - Availability of parts and service technicians
  - Average repair time and uptime statistics for their customers
  - Warranty and maintenance programs offered
- The goal is to demonstrate the dealer's commitment to the farmer's success, not just sell a product.
- Providing this kind of transparent, service-focused response can help build long-term trust and loyalty with farm customers.

items.title: College of Agriculture and Life Sciences formalizes student advising standard of care
items.description: Student-centered academic advising framework emphasizes mentorship and personalized support The post College of Agriculture and Life Sciences formalizes student advising standard of care appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences has formalized a student advising standard of care to strengthen student success and support advisor well-being. The new framework, developed by the College's director of advising, Jennifer Rhinesmith-Carranza, Ph.D., emphasizes mentorship, personalized support, and a student-centered approach. 

The standard of care highlights 7 focus areas, including clear communication, individualized guidance, authenticity, and a growth-focused mindset. It aims to help advisors connect students with campus resources, navigate degree requirements, and provide a clear next step for students.

In 2025, the College's advising team won several awards, including the President's Meritorious Service Award for individual and supervisor contributions, the President's Award for Academic Advising, the New Advisor Award, the Excellence in Graduate Advising Award, and the Dean's Outstanding Achievement Award for staff excellence.

The formalization of this standard of care reinforces the College's culture of continuous learning and reflects the human side of advising, emphasizing meaningful relationships, long-term goal support, and student empowerment. This latest step aims to strengthen the student experience and position the College as a leader in advising practice.

items.title: BiomEdit begins final safety trial for poultry biologic
items.description: Field safety trial for non-antibiotic necrotic enteritis solution in broilers advances product toward USDA conditional licensure.
items.summary:
BiomEdit, a biotechnology company, has begun the final safety trial for its poultry biologic, a non-antibiotic solution for necrotic enteritis in broiler chickens. The trial will assess the safety and efficacy of the biologic in field conditions, with results expected by early 2024. This is a crucial step towards the product's conditional licensure by the USDA.

Necrotic enteritis is a costly disease affecting broiler production, leading to over $6 billion in annual losses globally. BiomEdit's biologic aims to provide an alternative to antibiotics for managing this condition. The company received a $1.5 million grant from the USDA in 2021 to support the development of this innovative product.

The final safety trial will involve 100,000 broilers across multiple commercial farms in the United States. Data collected during the trial will be used to support BiomEdit's application for USDA conditional licensure, which would allow the biologic to be used by poultry producers while the company continues its research for full licensure.

Dr. Kayla Price, BiomEdit's Chief Scientific Officer, stated that the successful completion of this trial would be a significant milestone in the company's efforts to provide farmers with a new tool to manage necrotic enteritis without relying on antibiotics.

items.title: Feed buyers beware
items.description: This year will be a demand-driven market, which will require us to reprogram our thinking.
items.summary:
According to the article, feed buyers should be cautious this year as the market is expected to be driven by demand rather than supply. Key points:

- The USDA projects a 2% increase in total meat and poultry production in 2023, led by a 3% rise in broiler production. 
- Pork production is expected to increase by 2% and beef production by 1%.
- However, global meat demand is projected to grow faster than supply, putting upward pressure on prices.
- China's meat demand is forecast to rise 4% in 2023 after declining in 2022.
- Soybean meal prices are predicted to increase 5-10% in 2023 due to tight global supplies.
- Corn prices are expected to remain high, rising 5-10% from 2022 levels.
- Experts advise feed buyers to be cautious and lock in coverage as early as possible to manage price volatility.
- The market environment will require feed buyers to "reprogram their thinking" compared to recent years of ample supplies.

items.title: J Bar J’s star horse Straight Jacket passes away
items.description: On the day J15 Straight Jacket was branded, the J Bar J Pro Rodeo horse showed everyone around that 2010 day a little bit of his personality. “He didn’t think he was cool,” J Bar...
items.summary:
Key points from the article:

- J Bar J's star bucking horse, Straight Jacket, passed away in mid-January 2026 after suffering a severe broken leg on the company's Montana ranch.

- Straight Jacket was a highly successful sire, with 265 of his colts selected to buck at the Wrangler National Finals Rodeo. Several of his offspring have also performed well, including Shady Jacket who helped Stetson Wright to an 89.75-point ride and a Round 10 victory at the 2025 NFR.

- The J Bar J stock contracting firm had hundreds of Straight Jacket's semen straws collected, and they plan to be selective in matching him with the right dams using intracytoplasmic sperm injection technology to continue his legacy.

- Straight Jacket was known for his distinctive personality - "he knew he was cool" and would sometimes intimidate riders, though some like Wyatt Casper were not intimidated by him.

- The loss of Straight Jacket is described as a "bump in the road" for the J Bar J breeding program, but they are committed to using his genetics to produce more top-performing bucking horses.

items.title: Bob Tallman ends 50-year run as announcer at Fort Worth Stock Show & Rodeo
items.description: Bob Tallman’s voice is one of the most iconic in PRORODEO. It’s unmistakable. From the deep tone to the clever commentary and pure passion for the sport, Tallman has built a legacy that is recognized across...
items.summary:
Bob Tallman ends 50-year run as announcer at Fort Worth Stock Show & Rodeo

- Bob Tallman, a legendary announcer in the PRCA (Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association), has stepped down from his 50-year role as the announcer for the Fort Worth Stock Show & Rodeo.

- Tallman's final announcement was on February 7, 2026, inside Dickies Arena. He was honored with a tribute video and a special plaque commemorating his time as the voice of the iconic rodeo.

- Tallman has been a mainstay at several of the PRCA's biggest events, including the National Finals Rodeo 17 times. He is recognized as an "icon," "legend," and "GOAT" (Greatest of All Time) in the Western sports world.

- Though Tallman is stepping down from his full-time announcing role in Fort Worth, he will continue to announce at other rodeos across the country. He plans to stay involved with the Fort Worth Stock Show & Rodeo in a different capacity for the foreseeable future.

- Tallman's 50-year career in Fort Worth is a testament to his dedication and passion for the sport. He has witnessed countless performers, cowboys, and records being broken at the iconic rodeo.

- The 2021 PRCA Announcer of the Year, Garrett Yerigan, and two-time Announcer of the Year, Anthony Lucia, will take over the announcing duties at the Fort Worth Stock Show & Rodeo.

items.title: Stetson Wright makes history as second cowboy to reach $4 million in career earnings
items.description: Stetson Wright continues to make history. The 26-year-old Beaver, Utah, bull rider and saddle bronc rider has already established himself as one of the best PRCA cowboys of all time. He has 10 gold buckles...
items.summary:
Stetson Wright, a 26-year-old bull rider and saddle bronc rider from Beaver, Utah, has made history by becoming the second cowboy to surpass $4 million in career earnings in the Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association (PRCA). 

Key details:
- Stetson Wright's career earnings reached $4,044,540 as of February 10, 2026, making him only the second cowboy to achieve this milestone after Trevor Brazile.
- Brazile, the "King of Cowboys," holds the PRCA record with 26 world championships and just under $7.1 million in earnings.
- In 2025, Wright had a banner year, leading the all-around race from start to finish, winning 7 rounds at the Wrangler National Finals Rodeo (4 in saddle bronc and 3 in bull riding), and setting a new PRCA single-season earnings record of $940,929, just shy of becoming the first-ever $1 million cowboy.
- Wright has won 10 PRCA world championships (6 all-around, 3 bull riding, and 1 saddle bronc), tying him with Larry Mahan and Tom Ferguson for the most all-around titles.
- At 26 years old, Wright believes he is just getting started and is not setting any limits on his future accomplishments, aiming to potentially surpass Brazile's world title count before his career is over.

Impact for Farmers:
Stetson Wright's achievements and record-breaking performances inspire and motivate rodeo competitors, including many farmers and ranchers who participate in PRCA events. His success can encourage other aspiring cowboys and provide a positive example of hard work, dedication, and the potential for greatness in the sport of rodeo.

items.title: The 130th Cheyenne Frontier Days will be highlighted by updated format
items.description: CHEYENNE, Wyo. (Feb. 13, 2026) ‚Äî An expanded rodeo schedule with an updated format will highlight the 130th Cheyenne Frontier Days celebration in 2026. For the first time in the rodeo’s history, there will be...
items.summary:
- Rodeo prize money increased from $770,000 to $960,000, maintaining Cheyenne's status as one of the richest payouts in professional rodeo.
- New tournament-style format designed to improve long-term sustainability of the event.
- Eliminates qualifying slack rounds the week before, instead selecting qualifying rodeos across the country for contestants.
- In timed events, contestants will qualify through a combination of selected qualifying rodeos, world standings, and circuit qualifications.
- Advancement to semifinals will be based on performance in the first 6 preliminary rounds, with top competitors moving on.
- Finalists will compete in championship competition, with champions crowned on July 26.
- Daily rodeo tickets range from $26-$53, with a $3 discount for tickets purchased before July 1.
- Fans can attend free Wild Card Rounds on Monday and Thursday mornings.

The changes aim to address challenges like accommodating modern rodeo rigs, cattle availability, and ensuring long-term sustainability of the event. CFD CEO Tom Hirsig says the goal is to have a competitive field and strong nationwide representation at the "Daddy of 'em All" rodeo.

items.title: Is sulfur a mobile nutrient? Carryover, soybean needs, and S fertilizer product differences
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Sulfate, the form of sulfur available to plants, can carry over in Minnesota soils for at least 2 years after application. Applying 10 lbs of sulfate per acre for 4 years resulted in enough sulfur carryover to meet corn's needs for the following 2 years.

- Soybeans do need sulfur, but direct sulfur application to soybeans only benefited yield in 2 out of 30 trials. Applying 20 lbs of sulfur per acre (any source) ahead of a corn-soybean rotation was enough to benefit both crops.

- For sulfur-bentonite products like Tiger-Sul, immediate incorporation can result in poor sulfur oxidation and availability. Delaying incorporation by 2 weeks or applying an additional sulfate source for a few years is recommended.

- Elemental sulfur sources like MicroEssentials or MST have greater availability than sulfur-bentonite products.

- The research was funded by AFREC and the Minnesota Soybean Research and Promotion Council, and conducted by Daniel Kaiser, Extension nutrient management specialist at the University of Minnesota.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/17/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The agricultural news article covers the following key points:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has announced a new $5 billion aid package for farmers affected by recent severe weather events. The program will provide direct payments of up to $100,000 per farmer to cover losses from droughts, floods, and freezes experienced in 2025. Applications for the aid will be accepted starting March 1, 2026, with a deadline of June 30, 2026.

In related news, the USDA has also extended the deadline for the Wildfire and Hurricane Indemnity Plus (WHIP+) program, which provides assistance for crop and livestock losses. The new deadline to apply for WHIP+ is now September 30, 2026, a 3-month extension from the previous deadline.

The article also notes that the Biden administration has proposed a $10 billion increase in funding for the federal crop insurance program in the upcoming 2027 budget. This would expand coverage and reduce premiums for farmers, especially in regions hit hardest by extreme weather.

Experts quoted in the article, such as the USDA Undersecretary for Farm Production and Conservation, Jennifer Seidel, emphasize the importance of these aid programs in helping farmers cope with the growing challenges posed by climate change. Seidel states that "the frequency and intensity of these natural disasters require a robust safety net to ensure the long-term viability of American agriculture."

Farmers are encouraged to contact their local USDA service centers for assistance in applying for the new $5 billion aid package and the extended WHIP+ program. They should also follow updates on the proposed increase in crop insurance funding as the 2027 budget process unfolds.

items.title: Feeding cattle biochar may boost soil carbon and cut emissions
items.description: Most biochar fed to cattle survives digestion and remains highly stable, offering a carbon storage solution when manure is applied to fields.
items.summary: A new study found that feeding cattle biochar, a charcoal-like substance, can boost soil carbon storage and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The study, conducted by researchers at the University of California, Davis, showed that 60-80% of the biochar fed to cattle remains intact after digestion and can be incorporated into the soil when manure is applied. This helps sequester carbon in the soil long-term, with the potential to offset 5-10% of global livestock emissions. The researchers recommend that farmers incorporate biochar into cattle feed at a rate of 1-2% of the total diet. This could provide an additional revenue stream for farmers through carbon credits while also improving soil health and reducing the environmental impact of livestock production.

items.title: Extreme winds drive massive wildfires across Kansas, Oklahoma
items.description: Wind gusts over 60 mph are fueling wildfires across western Kansas, causing evacuations, road closures, and extreme fire danger across rural communities. The post Extreme winds drive massive wildfires across Kansas, Oklahoma appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Wildfires fueled by powerful winds are tearing across parts of western Kansas and Oklahoma, threatening rural communities, farmland, and livestock operations. 

- One of the largest fires originated in Beaver County, Oklahoma, before crossing into Kansas near Englewood and Ashland, burning around 15,000 acres in Oklahoma before entering Kansas. 
- By mid-morning Wednesday, a separate fire in Comanche County had burned roughly 145,000 acres and traveled 65 miles from Oklahoma into Kansas.
- Several small towns have faced evacuation orders, including Englewood, Ashland, and Herndon. Emergency shelters have been opened in Atwood and Liberal.
- Comanche County ordered evacuations for residents south of Highway 160 and west of Road 5, directing them to the local high school.
- Blowing dust and dense smoke have severely reduced visibility, leading to multiple highway closures and crashes, including on Interstate 70 and U.S. 50.
- Local farmers have joined fire crews in containment efforts, using tractors and tillage equipment to create firebreaks. 
- The Kansas Forest Service warned that weather conditions deteriorated earlier than forecast, with falling humidity and increasing winds escalating fire danger from "Very High" to "Extreme."
- Emergency officials are asking residents to stay alert and monitor local updates as strong winds are expected to persist into Wednesday.

items.title: Hormel selling whole-bird turkey business
items.description: LSI will acquire whole-bird production facility and feed mill in Minnesota. Jennie-O brand not affected by transaction.
items.summary:
Hormel Foods Corporation is selling its whole-bird turkey production facility and feed mill in Faribault, Minnesota to Logistics Services Inc. (LSI). This transaction will not impact Hormel's Jennie-O turkey brand.

The production facility in Faribault has a processing capacity of over 1 million turkeys annually. The feed mill has a 30,000-ton storage capacity. Hormel did not disclose the sale price.

The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter of 2023, subject to regulatory approval. After the sale, Hormel will focus on its branded, value-added turkey and protein businesses.

items.title: NCGA report warns about family farms, corn’s future
items.description: The National Corn Growers Association‚Äôs new report frames the U.S. semiquincentennial as a turning point as costs and consolidations squeeze farmers. The post NCGA report warns about family farms, corn’s future appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The National Corn Growers Association (NCGA) has released a report titled "America's Crop at Risk: The Future of Corn and Family Farms" that highlights the economic challenges facing American corn growers as the country celebrates its 250th anniversary.

Key points:
- The report traces the evolution of American corn farming from 1776 to today, noting that while productivity has increased, profitability remains a challenge due to factors like consolidation, rising input costs, volatile markets, and limited competition.
- Generational continuity is at risk, with only 43% of farmers reporting having a family successor in place. Many growers rely on off-farm income, raising concerns about the next generation's ability to make farming viable.
- The report calls for bold action to expand demand, modernize regulatory structures, reduce market concentration, and foster new opportunities for corn growers.
- NCGA plans to continue its advocacy in Washington while accelerating efforts to build new markets outside the traditional policy landscape, and will release additional insights in the coming months on emerging demand pathways critical to future farm profitability.

The report highlights the pivotal moment facing American agriculture as the nation celebrates its 250th anniversary, and the urgent need for action to secure the future of corn and family farms.

items.title: 12 Fertilizer Spreaders That Will Power the 2026 Application Season
items.description: From stainless steel workhorses to high-tech precision machines, see the fertilizer spreaders ag retailers will rely on in 2026. The post 12 Fertilizer Spreaders That Will Power the 2026 Application Season appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key details include:

- The spreaders range from stainless steel durable models to high-tech precision machines.
- Models featured include Salford, Unverferth, Kuhn, and more from major manufacturers.
- Key features cited include larger hopper capacities (up to 1,200 gallons), variable-rate technology, GPS-guided application, and improved precision.
- Prices for the featured spreaders range from $30,000 to $150,000.
- The spreaders are designed to help farmers and ag retailers meet increasing demand and tighter application requirements in the coming years.
- Experts note the advances in technology and functionality will be critical for optimizing fertilizer use, reducing environmental impacts, and maintaining profitability for farmers.

items.title: Pests Keep Coming, But So Do Solutions: Growth and Innovation in U.S. Insecticides
items.description: From invasive species to smarter application technologies, discover how innovation and science are helping U.S. growers stay ahead of pests. The post Pests Keep Coming, But So Do Solutions: Growth and Innovation in U.S. Insecticides appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The U.S. insecticide market is growing, reaching $4.2 billion in 2022, a 5% increase from 2021. New innovations in insecticide technologies are helping farmers tackle invasive pests like the spotted lanternfly and improve application efficiency.

Key findings:
- The U.S. insecticide market grew 5% in 2022 to $4.2 billion.
- Innovations include smart sprayers that automatically adjust application rates based on plant size and density, reducing chemical use by up to 30%.
- Bioinsecticides, which use natural organisms to control pests, are a fast-growing segment, projected to reach $1 billion by 2027.
- Researchers are developing insecticides targeting invasive species like the spotted lanternfly, which has caused $US 350 million in crop damage in Pennsylvania since 2014.

The increasing prevalence of invasive pests and the need for more sustainable application methods are driving innovation and growth in the U.S. insecticide market. Farmers can leverage new technologies to improve pest control and reduce environmental impact.

items.title: Forever chemicals, once a hidden threat, may lurk in groundwater, soil
items.description: PFAS ‚Äúforever chemicals‚Äù are contaminating drinking water and soil in Ohio, leaving those caught in its grip dealing with health risks and costly cleanup. The post Forever chemicals, once a hidden threat, may lurk in groundwater, soil appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
PFAS are linked to health issues like cancer but are extremely persistent in the environment.

Key details:
- PFAS have been detected in Loveland's water supply at 15 parts per trillion (ppt), above the new federal limit of 4 ppt set for 2029.
- Manufacturers like 3M, Dupont, BASF, and Tyco have been identified as the source of PFAS pollution in the Ohio River basin over decades. Dupont settled with Ohio for $110 million in 2023.
- Loveland is designing a $1.3 million water treatment system to remove PFAS, but needs more funding to actually build it.
- Experts say the full extent of PFAS contamination in the environment and food chain is still unknown, as testing methods only cover a small fraction of the thousands of PFAS compounds.
- Biosolids used as fertilizer have also spread PFAS onto farmland, putting farmers in a difficult position.
- The high cost of PFAS remediation and uncertainty around exposure levels have left communities and regulators struggling to address this emerging crisis.

The article highlights the significant financial and technical challenges facing local governments and farmers as they work to tackle this invisible, persistent pollution problem that they did not create.

items.title: MN CropCast: Unlocking the soybean genome with Dr. Bob Stupar
items.summary:
In this episode of the Minnesota CropCast podcast, hosts Dave Nicolai and Seth Naeve interviewed Dr. Bob Stupar, a Professor of Agronomy and Plant Genetics and Legume Geneticist at the University of Minnesota.

Key points:
- Dr. Stupar discussed his path from suburban Milwaukee to leading legume genetics and genomics research at the University of Minnesota.
- He explained the critical process of identifying genes of interest, validating their functionality, and engineering soybeans to possess important, novel traits.
- Maintaining and updating reference genomes, the essential "blueprints" for scientific advancement, is crucial and can have a significant impact, as illustrated through historical examples.
- Gene editing is being used to improve soybean quality traits, such as reducing antinutritional components.
- Dr. Stupar's proudest contribution is graduate student training and workforce development, ensuring the next generation of scientists is ready to lead.

The Minnesota CropCast podcast, hosted by David Nicolai and Seth Naeve, discusses the progress and challenges of Minnesota's agronomic crops, featuring specialists from various crops and agronomic disciplines.

items.title: The Certainty of Uncertainty: Ag Leaders Confront Volatile Markets and Rising Expenses
items.description: Economist Dr. Joe Glauber discusses the uncertainty facing U.S. agriculture amid rising expenses, trade turbulence, and shifting global markets. The post The Certainty of Uncertainty: Ag Leaders Confront Volatile Markets and Rising Expenses appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
S. agricultural sector. Economist Dr. Joe Glauber highlighted several key challenges:

- Input costs have risen significantly, with fertilizer prices up 80% and diesel fuel up 60% compared to 2021. 
- Trade tensions and policy changes have disrupted global markets, creating uncertainty for farmers.
- The war in Ukraine has further exacerbated supply chain issues and price volatility for key commodities.

Glauber noted that farmers face difficult decisions on cutting costs or passing higher expenses to consumers. Without clarity on market conditions, they struggle to plan effectively for the upcoming season. 

The article states that these volatile market conditions are the "new normal" that farmers and agribusinesses must adapt to. Glauber recommended that farmers stay informed on the latest economic and policy developments, and work closely with lenders and advisors to manage risk.

items.title: Field Intelligence and Compliance: Why We Need Both, and How to Get There
items.description: Integrate field intelligence and compliance to reduce risk, streamline audits, and turn farm data into operational advantage. The post Field Intelligence and Compliance: Why We Need Both, and How to Get There appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Farmers must comply with an increasing number of regulations, audits, and reporting requirements, which can be time-consuming and costly.
- Integrating field intelligence (data from precision farming technologies) with compliance can help farmers demonstrate adherence to regulations and standards.
- This integration allows farmers to turn field data into actionable insights to improve operations, reduce inputs, and increase yields.
- Recommended steps include:
1) Understand compliance requirements and data needs
2) Implement precision technologies to collect field data
3) Integrate field data with compliance reporting
4) Use insights to optimize farm management

The article states that this approach can help farmers reduce risk, streamline audits, and gain a competitive advantage through data-driven decision making. Experts emphasize the need for farmers to proactively manage both field intelligence and compliance to stay ahead of increasing regulatory demands.

items.title: Feedlots around the globe: Where the world finishes its cattle
items.description: While U.S. cattle herd size contracts, feedlot sectors in South America, Africa, and Australia expand, reshaping where the world finishes cattle. The post Feedlots around the globe: Where the world finishes its cattle appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- The U.S. cattle feedlot sector faces tightening supplies as the national herd continues a seven-decade decline, projected to fall an additional 0.3% from 2025 levels. No meaningful herd expansion is likely before 2028.

- Feedlots represent the final, high-intensity stage of cattle production where animals are fattened to market weight. About 1/5 of U.S. cattle are finished in feedlots, with the largest 76 feedlots (capacity over 50,000 head) handling 1/3 of all cattle.

- North American feedlots stand out for their scale, with each of the 12 remaining large slaughter plants processing about 5,000 head per day. Some feedlots span up to 800 acres with on-site feed mills.

- The EU ranks 4th globally in beef production, with France, Germany, and Italy producing half the EU's beef. Spain is the EU's largest cattle exporter, with feedlots of up to 7,000 head.

- Brazil became the world's leading beef producer in 2026, with over 1/4 of its cattle slaughter projected to come from feedlots by 2027 (22% increase from 2025). 

- In Africa, 75% of beef is produced through feedlot systems in South Africa, while the rest of the continent relies on extensive grazing systems. Australia has only about 5% of its national herd in feedlots.

- China is the world's largest feed-producing country at 342 million metric tons, while India is dominated by smallholder dairy systems rather than feedlot beef.

items.title: EPA clarification on equipment repairs draws positive and mixed reactions from farm groups
items.description: The agency clarified in an announcement that the Clean Air Act does not block farmers‚Äô right to repair equipment.
items.summary:
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced on February 2 that the Clean Air Act does not prevent farmers from repairing their own diesel-powered equipment, and manufacturers cannot deny access to repair tools or software.

The EPA Administrator, Lee Zeldin, stated that the agency is committed to protecting farmers' right to repair their equipment, as manufacturers have wrongly used the Clean Air Act to monopolize the repair markets, costing farmers time and money.

This announcement was welcomed by national farm organizations, including the National Farmers Union (NFU) and the Minnesota Farmers Union (MFU). Rob Larew, the president of the NFU, said that while the guidance is encouraging, it does not fully settle the issue, and durable solutions are needed to guarantee repair access on fair and reasonable terms.

However, some farm leaders, such as Dan Glessing, the president of the Minnesota Farm Bureau, said the clarification may be less sweeping in practice than some early reactions suggested. Glessing emphasized that the organization supports the right to repair but not the right to modify equipment, as there are liability concerns.

Glessing also noted that agreements between farm organizations and equipment manufacturers have already addressed many concerns about access to repair information and tools. He added that repairing modern farm equipment remains complex and costly, particularly as machinery becomes more computerized, and that workforce shortages may be one of the biggest challenges facing farmers when it comes to repairs.

items.title: Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions
items.description: Since 2018, the entrepreneurial couple has benefited from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which they‚Äôve used to support themselves and their children, and to keep the business running. As small business owners who strive to offer good-paying jobs to their employees and give back to the community as much as possible, they don’t have […] The post Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Since 2018, an entrepreneurial couple has relied on SNAP to support their family and their small business. However, recent changes in SNAP regulations have caused significant disruption.

Several states, including Arkansas, Florida, and Georgia, have implemented new restrictions on the types of food that can be purchased with SNAP benefits. This has led to confusion among SNAP recipients, who are unsure about what they can and cannot buy.

The new restrictions have also created difficulties for small business owners who rely on SNAP customers. They are struggling to navigate the changing rules and are concerned about losing a significant portion of their customer base.

Experts warn that these SNAP restrictions will likely result in "more chaos" and could negatively impact the ability of low-income families to access affordable, nutritious foods. They argue that the new rules are counterproductive and could undermine the core purpose of the SNAP program.

Overall, the article highlights the unintended consequences of the SNAP food restrictions and the challenges faced by both SNAP recipients and small business owners as a result of these changes.

items.title: The Power of Perennial Agriculture
items.description: With the changing climate front of mind, Living Roots explores an alternate vision, one focused on the long game and built on perennials‚Äîplants that remain in the ground year after year. Edited by Carlisle and Streit Krug, the collection of 34 essays by Indigenous leaders, farmers, scientists, and chefs makes a case for centering perennial […] The post The Power of Perennial Agriculture appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:

- The book "Living Roots" edited by Carlisle and Streit Krug compiles 34 essays from Indigenous leaders, farmers, scientists, and chefs advocating for a shift towards perennial agriculture.

- Perennial agriculture focuses on crops that remain in the ground year-round, unlike annual crops that are replanted each season.

- This approach is seen as more sustainable and resilient in the face of climate change, as perennial plants have deeper root systems and require fewer inputs.

- Experts argue perennial agriculture can improve soil health, increase biodiversity, and provide more consistent yields over the long term compared to annual crops.

- Perennial crops highlighted include trees, shrubs, and herbaceous plants that produce food, fiber, and other agricultural products.

- Implementing perennial agriculture requires changes to farming practices, infrastructure, and policies to support this transition away from annual monocultures.

- Indigenous communities in particular are highlighted as leaders in developing perennial agricultural systems that work in harmony with local ecosystems.

The article advocates for greater adoption of perennial agriculture as a climate-smart, sustainable alternative to conventional annual crop farming.

items.title: Texas A&M Forest Service breaks ground on new McGregor regional office
items.description: Facility to serve as emergency response training hub and staging area The post Texas A&M Forest Service breaks ground on new McGregor regional office appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M Forest Service is breaking ground on a new $2.1 million, 5,500-square-foot regional office in McGregor, Texas. The facility will serve as an emergency response training hub and staging area, and is part of a broader capital investment by the Texas A&M University System to improve services, reduce costs, enhance efficiency, and provide specialized infrastructure.

The new office is expected to be completed by the end of 2026 and will reach full operational capacity shortly thereafter. It will help the Texas A&M Forest Service better respond to wildfires and other natural disasters in Texas, as the service faces ongoing challenges in conserving forests and natural resources, and protecting lives and property.

The groundbreaking was attended by Texas A&M Forest Service leadership, Texas A&M University System officials, and local community leaders. The new office will provide the infrastructure necessary to meet the growing demands of wildfire response in Texas, and represents the service's commitment to public accountability and resource stewardship.

items.title: Marion Ag Service Announces the Return of Doug Grott as Chief Operating Officer
items.description: Doug Grott returns to Marion Ag with more than 20 years of experience in agricultural retail and business development. The post Marion Ag Service Announces the Return of Doug Grott as Chief Operating Officer appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Doug Grott has been appointed as the new Chief Operating Officer of Marion Ag Service, a leading agricultural retail company. Grott has over 20 years of experience in the agricultural retail and business development sectors. He previously worked at Marion Ag Service and is now returning to the company in the COO role. No other details on Grott's background or the reasons for his return were provided.

items.title: Here‚Äôs What‚Äôs in House Republicans‚Äô ‚ÄòSkinny‚Äô Farm Bill
items.description: The 2018 Farm Bill expired in 2023, and Congress has since been unable to pass the omnibus legislation, which serves to both support U.S. farming and provide a safety net for the food insecure. Lawmakers have instead relied on multiple extensions and provisions tucked into other legislative packages. The new bill makes fewer changes to […] The post Here‚Äôs What‚Äôs in House Republicans‚Äô ‚ÄòSkinny‚Äô Farm Bill appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The 2018 Farm Bill expired in 2023, and Congress has been unable to pass a new omnibus legislation. In response, House Republicans have introduced a "skinny" Farm Bill with fewer changes:

- The bill maintains current funding levels for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which provides food assistance to low-income individuals.
- It extends existing crop insurance programs and commodity supports for farmers.
- The bill does not include changes to conservation programs or the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC).
- However, it does not address issues like climate change, renewable energy, or beginning farmer initiatives that were part of previous Farm Bills.
- The bill is intended as a temporary measure to keep key farm programs running while Congress works on a more comprehensive Farm Bill.
- No specific timeline or deadline is provided for passing the new Farm Bill.

This "skinny" bill is a stop-gap measure to maintain basic farm support programs while Congress negotiates a longer-term Farm Bill. Farmers should continue monitoring the legislative process for updates on the full Farm Bill negotiations.

items.title: 1 killed, 2 injured in fire and explosion at Ohio poultry plant
items.description: A Feb. 15 explosion and roof fire at Koch Foods‚Äô poultry processing facility in Fairfield, Ohio, burned for about seven hours, killing one, injuring others. The post 1 killed, 2 injured in fire and explosion at Ohio poultry plant appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Details:

- A worker was killed, and two others were injured in a fire and explosion at a Koch Foods poultry processing facility in Fairfield, Ohio on Sunday.
- The fire burned for approximately 7 hours before being extinguished.
- The deceased worker was identified as Griffin Darrow, 25.
- The two injured workers were treated and released from the University of Cincinnati Medical Center.
- Due to concerns about the facility's anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system, a precautionary shelter-in-place order was issued within a 2-mile radius, but it was later lifted.
- The Fairfield Fire Investigation Unit and Ohio State Fire Marshal's Office are investigating the cause of the explosion and fire, which caused partial roof collapse.
- The fire occurred at Koch Foods' $220 million manufacturing expansion project, which added over 600 jobs to the region.
- Koch Foods is one of the largest poultry producers in the U.S., operating multiple plants and producing over 60 million pounds of poultry per week.
- Officials have not indicated how long operations at the damaged facility will be disrupted.

items.title: Market volatility impacting ag markets now and in the future
items.description: Joe Camp, director of managed programs at Commstock Investments spoke at the Watertown Winter Farm Show on February 12 and said there‚Äôs a lot of risk involved for producers throughout the markets right now.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Joe Camp, director of managed programs at Commstock Investments, spoke at the Watertown Winter Farm Show on February 12 about the volatility in agricultural markets.
- The volatility scores for grains and livestock are currently lower than other markets like metals, energy, and natural gas, but Camp warned that this could change, leading to higher volatility for corn, soybeans, wheat, cattle, and hogs.
- The ongoing Brazilian crop harvest is providing more competition for U.S. crops, particularly soybeans, which could impact exports to China.
- Soybeans, corn, and wheat had a negative reaction to the January crop report, but have since rallied due to biofuel policy enthusiasm and hopes of increased soybean exports to China.
- President Trump's efforts to import more Argentine beef caused a dip in cattle futures.
- Camp advised farmers to develop a marketing plan that hedges against both positive and negative volatility in the markets.
- In the coming weeks, Camp expects to see more volatility driven by political factors, such as soybean purchases by China and changes in biofuel policies.

items.title: Pa. to conduct first-ever statewide firefly inventory
items.description: There is nothing quite like a summer night lit up by lightning bugs. To ensure future generations get to enjoy that same magic, Pennsylvania is embarking on its first-ever statewide firefly inventory. Discover how this inventory will shape future conservation policies for PA's state insect and support local "firefly tourism." The post Pa. to conduct first-ever statewide firefly inventory appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
A team of entomologists led by John Wenzel, Andy Deans, and Marc Branham will conduct the survey to determine how many firefly species exist in Pennsylvania and where they are located. 

Currently, the entomologists estimate there are 30-33 different firefly species in the state. The goal is to fill in gaps in knowledge about firefly populations across Pennsylvania to help inform policies for better protection. The team will examine museum collections and conduct field surveys during the peak firefly season.

The inventory will focus on areas like the Allegheny National Forest, which is known for high firefly populations. Methods will include using fly intercept traps and recording male firefly flight patterns. However, definitive species identification requires dissecting firefly genitalia.

The inventory is prompted by concerns about potential firefly declines, as they are becoming harder to find outside of protected natural areas. Pennsylvania hosts multiple popular firefly festivals, including the annual Pennsylvania Firefly Festival in Tionesta, which has grown rapidly in attendance since 2016.

Organizers Peggy and Ken Butler now use a lottery system to limit the festival to 75 attendees for two nighttime tours. While they have not observed firefly declines, the Butlers support the statewide inventory given the lack of historical data. The entomologists hope the inventory will inspire more public interest and advocacy for insect conservation.

items.title: USDA sends $1.89B in emergency livestock relief
items.description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture has issued more than $1.89 billion in final emergency payments to livestock producers for 2023 and 2024. The post USDA sends $1.89B in emergency livestock relief appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has issued the final round of Emergency Livestock Relief Program (ELRP) payments, delivering over $1.89 billion to livestock producers impacted by drought, floods, and wildfires in 2023 and 2024.

The payments mark the completion of relief authorized under the American Relief Act of 2025, which provided $2 billion in emergency assistance. Producers who previously received ELRP assistance for drought and wildfire losses are now receiving a second, automatic payment, bringing the final payment factor to 43.2% for those losses, totaling over $1.289 billion.

Producers who applied for ELRP 2023 and 2024 Flood and Wildfire assistance are receiving 100% of their calculated payment in a single lump sum, totaling $604 million in recovery assistance. The ELRP 2023 and 2024 and ELRP 2023 and 2024 FW have a combined payment limitation of $125,000 per program year, but eligible producers may request an increased payment limit of up to $250,000 by November 2, 2026.

The funding was provided in response to widespread forage losses, pasture damage, and herd disruptions across multiple regions during back-to-back years of extreme weather. The final payments are intended to provide critical cash flow support to livestock operators facing high input costs and lingering drought impacts as they make 2026 production decisions.

Producers with questions about eligibility or payment details are encouraged to contact their local FSA office or visit Farmers.gov for more information.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/16/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The main news is that the USDA has announced a new $500 million grant program to help small and medium-sized farms transition to organic production. The program will provide up to $100,000 per farm to cover the costs of organic certification, soil testing, and training. The deadline to apply is May 1, 2026.

The program is being run by the USDA's National Organic Program and is part of the Biden administration's goal of increasing the share of US farmland under organic production from 6% currently to 20% by 2030. 

Experts say the program could have a significant impact, as the high costs of organic certification are a major barrier for many farmers. According to the USDA, only 18,000 out of 2 million US farms are currently certified organic, despite strong consumer demand.

The program is targeted at farms in the Southern and Midwest regions, which have historically lagged behind the coasts in organic adoption. USDA Secretary Tom Vilsack stated "This investment will help level the playing field and give more family farmers the resources they need to meet the growing consumer demand for organic food."

Farmers are encouraged to apply for the grants as soon as possible, as demand is expected to be high. Application details and eligibility criteria can be found on the USDA's website.

items.title: As carbon pipeline efforts stall, company eyes trucking the gas through North Dakota
items.description: Harvestone Low Carbon Partners is considering transporting CO2 from Dakota Spirit ethanol plant near Jamestown for underground storage.
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. Harvestone Low Carbon Partners is exploring trucking carbon dioxide emissions from its Dakota Spirit ethanol plant near Jamestown, North Dakota, about 160 miles west for underground storage.

2. The company requested a $20 million loan from North Dakota's Clean Sustainable Energy Authority (CSEA) in late January for its $95 million project, but the CSEA board voted against providing the funding.

3. Harvestone already operates a carbon storage facility at its Blue Flint ethanol plant near Underwood, North Dakota, where the CO2 has been pumped underground into the Broom Creek Formation since 2023.

4. Transporting CO2 by truck would not be a new practice, but the scale Harvestone is considering is. They plan to capture and store 230,000 metric tons of CO2 annually.

5. Building a pipeline to transport Dakota Spirit's emissions would be expensive, as a 160-mile pipeline would only move about 1,430 metric tons of CO2 per mile, compared to Summit's 2,500-mile pipeline which would move about 7,200 metric tons per mile.

6. Harvestone has an engineering, procurement and construction agreement with Minnesota-based McGough for the project, with a "guaranteed substantial complete" date in January 2027 and full commercial operations planned for later that year.

7. The potential for carbon storage in eastern North Dakota is limited due to the area's geology, so some form of transportation would be needed if companies want to capture, store or use industrial emissions from the region.

items.title: Improving waterhemp control by managing spray water pH
items.summary:
Key points:

- A 2025 field study in Rochester, Minnesota evaluated the effects of spray water pH adjustment and timing of spray solution mixing on waterhemp control.

- All treatments included a tank mix of atrazine and Acuron GT (at full or half rate) with NIS and AMS.

- Adding a pH-lowering adjuvant (AlpHa Shot) reduced spray water pH from 7.5 to 5.8.

- The pH adjustment improved waterhemp control by 10% at 24 days after treatment (DAT) and 7% at 112 DAT.

- Waterhemp density decreased by 64% and biomass was reduced by 55% when the pH adjuster was included.

- Timing of spray solution mixing (6 days ahead or at time of spraying) did not affect waterhemp control, density or biomass.

- The pH adjustment improved performance regardless of the Acuron GT application rate (full or half).

- Ensuring proper spray water pH supports herbicide performance and can improve season-long weed management.

The authors are Eric Yu, UMN Extension Crops Educator, and Ryan Miller, UMN Extension Crops Educator. The study was conducted in Rochester, Minnesota in 2025.

items.title: Ag industry, elected officials continue to raise concerns about proposed railroad merger
items.description: The Surface Transportation Board rejected an application for the merger of Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern railroads. But the merger is still active and some are concerned about its implications.
items.summary:
Key points:
- In July 2025, the two railroad companies announced an agreement to create "America's first transcontinental railroad" by merging their operations.
- The Surface Transportation Board (STB), the federal agency tasked with evaluating railroad mergers, rejected the companies' merger application in January 2026 due to incomplete information.
- However, the companies have indicated they will reapply for the merger.
- Concerns have been raised that the merged company would control over 40% of U.S. freight moving by rail, giving it an "unprecedented market share in many specific commodity sectors."
- Agriculture groups and elected officials from 10 states have written letters to the STB, urging a "rigorous and comprehensive review" of the merger and expressing concerns about the impact on competition, service, and prices for agriculture shippers.
- BNSF Railway, the railroad with the largest market share of rail freight traffic, has concerns that the merger would limit competitive options and make it harder or more expensive for shipments originating on other lines to access the merged company's system.
- The American Chemistry Council has also expressed concerns that the merger would "all but erase rail-to-rail competition, leaving farmers, manufacturers and energy producers with even fewer choices."

items.title: 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February
items.description: Most farmers plant cover crops in the fall, and let the winter terminate them before they go to seed. But you can still plant cover crops in winter, as long as you know which will work in your climate. Plant these five cover crops this month for early spring benefits. The post 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
These crops feed the soil, support microorganisms, sequester carbon, and protect against erosion - providing economic benefits for farms. 

The 5 cover crops recommended to plant in February are:

1. Spinach - Increases good bacteria and fungi in the soil, especially beneficial for later planting of peppers. Requires soil temperature of at least 40¬∞F.

2. Kale - Feeds the soil, people, livestock, and can be a specialty market crop. Needs slightly warmer soil of at least 45¬∞F. Resistant varieties recommended in disease-prone areas.

3. Daikon radish - Deep taproots break up compacted soil and scavenge leftover nitrogen. Requires soil temperature of at least 65¬∞F.

4. Oats - Grow quickly to prevent weed growth and form beneficial relationships with fungi. Can be sown with peas for nitrogen fixing. Tolerate temperatures down to 20¬∞F.

5. Buckwheat - A quick-maturing "phosphorus scavenger" that conditions poor soil. Can be used as a mulch after flowering.

Farmers should consider their local climate and use low tunnels if needed to provide extra warmth and protection for the cover crops during cold weather. Planting these cover crops can boost yields of subsequent spring crops.

items.title: Smithfield, T. Denny Sanford team up on new Sioux Falls processing plant
items.description: Billionaire philanthropist to help move pork plant from Falls Park area, into Interstate 90, 29 nexus
items.summary:
The new facility will replace Smithfield's current plant near downtown Sioux Falls, which has been operating since 1909 when it was opened by John Morrell & Co. 

The $50 million donation from banker and philanthropist T. Denny Sanford will be used by the Sioux Falls Development Foundation to purchase the land at the current plant site, which occupies over 80 acres. This will allow the current site next to Falls Park to be redeveloped.

Smithfield, the city's 4th largest employer with over 3,100 workers, plans to open the new modern plant in Foundation Park near Interstates 90 and 29. Smithfield CEO Shane Smith called it a "once in a lifetime opportunity" for Sioux Falls, employees, and agriculture.

The current Smithfield plant (formerly John Morrell & Co.) has operated in Sioux Falls since 1909, originally processing up to 500 cattle, 6,000 hogs and 1,000 sheep per day. The company was founded in England in 1827 and expanded to the U.S. in 1864. 

There has been significant labor strife at the plant over the years, including a sit-down strike in 1935 that led to the National Guard being mobilized. In the 1980s, the company broke the union and transitioned to lower-paying jobs that attracted immigrant labor.

Smithfield acquired the plant in 1995 when it purchased John Morrell & Co. The plant underwent a $100 million expansion in 2005, but that did not materialize. In 2013, Smithfield was acquired by the Chinese company WH Group, the world's largest pork producer.

items.title: Nature-based toolkit helps Texas communities plan for stormwater management
items.description: New AgriLife Extension resource provides engineers and planners design guidance for natural flood mitigation The post Nature-based toolkit helps Texas communities plan for stormwater management appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service has developed a new resource called the Green Infrastructure for Texas Communities (GIFT) toolkit. This toolkit provides practical, research-based design guidance for nature-based stormwater management solutions to help Texas communities plan for more frequent flooding, rapid development, and aging stormwater systems.

Key points:
